title: How to send a password securely
excerpt: Stop sending credentials in chat apps. Use one-time secrets with expiry and view limits.

content.text: How to send a password securely sounds simple until you remember how real life works. Most breaches are not movie-hacker moments; they’re normal workflows that quietly leak data over time. This is mostly about reducing the number of ways humans can accidentally create a permanent copy: screenshots, forwarding, sync backups, shared devices, browser history, and the classic 'I’ll paste it here just for a second'. Good security keeps working even when someone is tired, rushed, or slightly overconfident.

The goal is practical control, not perfect behavior. If your policy assumes everyone is disciplined 100% of the time, you’re building a museum exhibit, not a system. This is mostly about reducing the number of ways humans can accidentally create a permanent copy: screenshots, forwarding, sync backups, shared devices, browser history, and the classic 'I’ll paste it here just for a second'. Good security keeps working even when someone is tired, rushed, or slightly overconfident.

content.title: Principle
content.text: Design for humans. Minimize copies. Limit time. Limit access. Rotate when it matters.
Why passwords leak in normal workflows

Chats, emails, and tickets are built to keep information around. That’s great for collaboration, but it’s the opposite of what you want for credentials. This is mostly about reducing the number of ways humans can accidentally create a permanent copy: screenshots, forwarding, sync backups, shared devices, browser history, and the classic 'I’ll paste it here just for a second'. Good security keeps working even when someone is tired, rushed, or slightly overconfident.

items: Chat history gets backed up and synced across devices
Notifications can preview secrets on lock screens
People forward messages without thinking
Screenshots turn 'temporary' into 'forever'
Password reuse multiplies the blast radius

content.text: A safer pattern: one-time delivery + short expiry

Use a one-time secret link with an expiry and a single view. That way, even if the link is forwarded later, it’s useless after the first open. This is mostly about reducing the number of ways humans can accidentally create a permanent copy: screenshots, forwarding, sync backups, shared devices, browser history, and the classic 'I’ll paste it here just for a second'. Good security keeps working even when someone is tired, rushed, or slightly overconfident.
Recommended defaults

items: View limit: 1
Expiry: 15–60 minutes (shorter for production access)
Add a passphrase for high-risk credentials
Never deliver passphrase in the same channel as the link
Rotate the password after the task is done

content.text: Security that depends on perfect behavior is wishful thinking with a budget.
content.by: Everyone who learned it the hard way

content.text: Checklist before you send anything

items: Does this credential have least privilege?
Can it be rotated quickly?
Will the recipient open it immediately?
Is the channel split (link vs passphrase) if needed?
Will this end up in a ticketing system or shared inbox?
